conclusion: Analyze the movement of the conductor rod MN in the magnetic field to determine the induced voltage and current direction.

The image shows two parallel straight guide-rails labeled ab and cd, separated by a distance l. A fixed resistor R is connected between points b and d. A conductor rod MN is placed on the guide-rails, perpendicular to them, and its resistance is also R. A uniform magnetic field with induction intensity B is applied, perpendicular to the plane of the guide-rails. The rod MN moves uniformly along the guide-rails at a speed v.
The conductor rod MN is moving uniformly along the guide-rails at a speed v.
The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the guide-rails, and the rod MN is perpendicular to the guide-rails, so the magnetic field is perpendicular to the rod's motion.
The motion of MN in the magnetic field induces an electromotive force (EMF) across it, given by the equation EMF = Bvl.
The induced EMF causes a current to flow in the rod MN. Since the rod's resistance is R, the current I is given by I = EMF/R = Bvl/R.
The current flows from point M to point N, as indicated by the direction of the induced EMF.
The current flowing through the fixed resistor R is in the same direction as the current in the rod MN, from M to N.
Therefore, the direction of the induced current in the fixed resistor R is from point b to point d.
The magnitude of the voltage U across MN is Bvl, and the direction of the induced current flowing through the fixed resistor R is from point b to point d.
